author: holiman
content: PSA: I think 1559 has a vulnerability: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/22963

author: holiman
content: TLDR; transactions can be arbitrarily large. The only practical limits are on the implementation side: the `10Mb` rlp packet size limit, and whatever limits used in various pool implementations. As far as the consensus-engine goes, a 12MGas block can become hundreds of megabytes. Or petabytes, whatever.

author: holiman
content: I don't think it's very hard to fix, e..g by limiting the fields to `64` or `256` bits, but I _do_ think we need a last-minute change to 1559.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: IIUC, you are proposing that someone could just pass a very large integer as one of the transaction parameters, but isn't that possible with any of the transaction parameters today?

author: .fjl
content: It is prevented by the tx cost checks of the validation

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, I think I see.  The issue is that previously if you tried to use a stupidly large integer for gasPrice, you would have to be able to afford that big number.

author: sky.cactus
content: And all of the other QUANTITY fields in a legacy transaction are similarly constrained in size.  ü§î

author: holiman
content: None of the ones today are ignored. So yes, you can specify a huge price, but that reflects on the cost, so ...

author: sky.cactus
content: Excellent catch!

author: sky.cactus
content: My recommendation for remediation is to put a hard cap on these numbers (as I think we should do for other QUANTITY values, but that is a separate discussion).

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., nonce < 2^53, gasLimit <= 2^32, timestamp <= 2^32, etc.

author: holiman
content: For context: a similar variant that can be done is in the eth protocol. where you can announce a head TD of several megabytes. We have that test in the eth-protocol tests on hive

author: sky.cactus
content: IIRC, Geth already uses a uint64 for `nonce` internally?

author: holiman
content: Yes

author: holiman
content: I agree that we should put caps on things.

author: sky.cactus
content: Since we are close to (maybe across) the code freeze, it probably would go over better to only cap these two and not try to cap all QUANTITY fields at once (despite me desiring that).

author: sky.cactus
content:
Possible Solutions:
[1]
```ts
require(sender.balance >= gasLimit * maxFeePerGas)
require(sender.balance >= gasLimit * maxPriorityFeePerGas)
```[2]
```ts
require(sender.balance >= gasLimit * maxFeePerGas)
require(maxFeePerGas >= maxPriorityFeePerGas)
```[3]
```ts
require(maxFeePerGas < 2^256)
require(maxPriorityFeePerGas < 2^256)
```

author: holiman
content:
If we have these two rules
```
require(maxFeePerGas >= maxPriorityFeePerGas) # Makes sense that the total is larger than a part thereof
require(sender.balance >= gasLimit * maxFeePerGas) # The sender needs to be able to cover the full max resources he's claiming
```
Then whether it's `256` or `64` is really an implementation detail
